Title(s): On the King’s Breaking the Magna Charta
Subjects: abuses, of the age; Edward II, criticism of; political poems
Versification: — four-line, six-line, three-line — abab, aabccb, aaa
_description: The Abuses of the Age: On the King’s Breaking the Magna Charta — English lines in varying stanzas, with alternate Anglo-Norman lines at the beginning

CamStJohn112.First Lines:
Rome poet fere e defere Si fet ele trop souentþat nis
                    noþer wel ne veyrefor þi is holy cherche
                    ysend…
CamStJohn112.Last Lines:
…Curt and laghe hundred a syre al it god aduuele
                    vay
CamStJohn112.Note:
According to Brown  and  Robbins (1943)
XCarleton Fairchild Brown,   and  Rossell Hope Robbins.  
             The Index of Middle English Verse.
         New York: Printed for the Index Society by Columbia University Press,
            1943 the text has 12 lines: actually 1 x 16 and 1 x
                    8, abababababababab and abababab; or 3 x 8 with same rhymes in first two
                    stanzas; written two lines of verse per line of MS.

Aspin,  Isabel Stewart Tod. 
             Anglo-Norman Political Songs.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1953: 62-3.

NLS1921.First Lines:
Len puet fere et defere ceo fait il trop souventIt nis nouther wel
                    ne faire þerfore engelond is shent…
NLS1921.Last Lines:
…Sen him þat us bouhte dereIn ioye wid oute
                    ende
NLS1921.Attributed Title: Un sarmoun of iiij wise men (f. 105ra)
